The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$

The alternating group on $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, denoted as $\mathfrak{A}_{n}$, is the set of all even permutations in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, i.e., those permutations for which $\operatorname{sgn} \pi = 1$. It forms a normal subgroup of index 2 in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$.
Does the concept of a/an Center need to be defined for a definition of a/an Alternating Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of an Alternating Group does not inherently require the concept of a Center. The Alternating Group is defined based on the properties of permutations (specifically, even permutations) and their relationship to the symmetric group $\\(\mathfrak{S}_{n}\\)$. The definition focuses on the nature of permutations and their signs, and it establishes the Alternating Group as a subgroup of the symmetric group without any reference to the concept of a Center.\n\nThe concept of a Center, on the other hand, pertains to the elements of a group that commute with all other elements in the group. While the Center is an important concept in group theory for understanding the structure of groups, it is not necessary to define or understand the Alternating Group. The Center of a group might be relevant in more advanced studies of group properties, but it is not required for the basic definition or understanding of what an Alternating Group is.
